thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: Fitzroy's Spanish club building to make way for apartments
thread.title_full: Fitzroy's Spanish club building to make way for apartments

title: Fitzroy's Spanish club building to make way for apartments
text:
Tim Gurner rejigged apartment sizes in his Stanley Street development in Collingwood to meet the market.
The home and birthplace of Melbourne's popular Spanish street festival, Fitzroy's Spanish club on Johnston Street, will be transformed into apartments in a deal between the club and young rich-lister Tim Gurner's development company.
Financial pressure from dwindling club memberships has prompted a development partnership that will see a $35 million seven-level apartment building launch on the site in mid-2016 if local authorities grant planning approval.
The club, originally known as the Spanish Roman Catholic Mission before being renamed Hogar Español (which translates as Spanish Home), has had a home in the two-level building at 57-61 Johnston Street since 1969.
Tim Gurner, a young rich-lister, has done a deal with Fitzroy's Spanish Club on Johnson Street to turn the club into apartments. Photo: Simon O'Dwyer
Mr Gurner said the new building's proposed design would echo Spanish mansion architecture.
The deal will guarantee the survival of the club and see it continue in facilities on the ground floor where it will also run a Spanish bar and restaurant, he said.
Club president Margarita Ros said falling membership had precipitated the decision.
"Unfortunately in recent years the club's operations had become unsustainable due to falling membership numbers so we were faced with the prospect of either closing our doors – which would have a devastating impact on the Spanish and wider community – or thinking outside the box to work in partnership with a developer," she said.
The club founded the annual Johnston Street Festival which shuts down the street for a day.
Other migrant social clubs in Melbourne are also struggling.
The historic Celtic Club, Australia's oldest Irish club, on the corner of Queen and La Trobe streets has a chequered history of attempting to resolve similar financial troubles.
It initially inked a development deal with Buildcorp for its heritage-listed building but failed to get members' approval and instead moved to quietly sell the site for a speculated $25 million before that too fell over, leaving the club in limbo.
Mr Gurner's development group is responsible for several projects near the Spanish club, including apartments in the historic Foy and Gibson factory at 107 Cambridge Street, more at 28 Stanley Street and the Oxley, Little Ox and Bellini developments.
All three towers in Gurner's Fortitude Valley development in Brisbane have sold. The first two towers with 650 apartments are under construction.
The group is expecting to settle on another two sites in Brisbane for 500 apartments and will launch an upmarket development in South Melbourne within the next two months, Mr Gurner said.
